Follow the leader.  # Follow the leader is the most suitable English idiom to match the definition of the Chinese idiom 萧规曹随.  # The Chinese idiom 萧规曹随 literally means "Xiaogui Cao sui", which is a phrase from the "Zuo Zhuan" (a historical text from the Spring and Autumn period), referring to the fact that when the Xiaogui family was in power, Cao Sui would follow their rules and regulations. The idiom is used to describe someone who is always ready to follow the crowd or the leader. The English idiom "Follow the leader" is a direct translation of the Chinese idiom's meaning, making it the most suitable choice.  # The other two options, "Go with the flow" and "Follow the pack", do not accurately convey the same meaning as the Chinese idiom, as they imply a more passive or instinctual following, rather than a deliberate choice to follow the leader.  # Therefore, "Follow the leader" is the best English idiom to match the definition of the Chinese idiom 萧规曹随.  #
